snippet.textDisplay: Is this a Windows thing?
snippet.textOriginal: Is this a Windows thing?

snippet.textDisplay: Wait, what? There's seriously a company out there selling something that's existed for free on Linux for years? This is literally Timeshift, only not FOSS. I have regularly scheduled timeshift snapshots RSYNC-ed (but you can also use BTRFS) to a separate drive at intervals I select (I run Arch, so I have them set to "Daily" lol), and you can keep as few or as many as you want, and also create on-demand snapshots as well. Plus, if something happens to your actual physical drive the OS is on, all you have to do is boot up a live usb, copy the files from one of your snapshots onto a new drive, and you're up and running. It seriously boggles my mind that simple things like this aren't built into Windows the way they are Linux.
snippet.textOriginal: Wait, what? There's seriously a company out there selling something that's existed for free on Linux for years? This is literally Timeshift, only not FOSS. I have regularly scheduled timeshift snapshots RSYNC-ed (but you can also use BTRFS) to a separate drive at intervals I select (I run Arch, so I have them set to "Daily" lol), and you can keep as few or as many as you want, and also create on-demand snapshots as well. Plus, if something happens to your actual physical drive the OS is on, all you have to do is boot up a live usb, copy the files from one of your snapshots onto a new drive, and you're up and running. It seriously boggles my mind that simple things like this aren't built into Windows the way they are Linux.

snippet.textDisplay:
1. If popup asking to block or to not is considered security for you, then sorry to disappoint you don't need windows defender or any other antivirus, you can just enable built-in UAC in windows
2. Backups is not magic silver bullet for such malware since most people store backups on same machine, where it's high risk of being encrypted along with the rest of files. Why? Cloud is not cheap, NAS is bulky and average user won't get one. Even if u use free tiers of clouds, for most people full volume upload will take weeks or months (since fibre optics is still not available in most of locations). And all this is along with fact that such malware can come with bonus trojans and keyloggers to get access to you backup accounts to get it all washed our. Great.
snippet.textOriginal:
1. If popup asking to block or to not is considered security for you, then sorry to disappoint you don't need windows defender or any other antivirus, you can just enable built-in UAC in windows
2. Backups is not magic silver bullet for such malware since most people store backups on same machine, where it's high risk of being encrypted along with the rest of files. Why? Cloud is not cheap, NAS is bulky and average user won't get one. Even if u use free tiers of clouds, for most people full volume upload will take weeks or months (since fibre optics is still not available in most of locations). And all this is along with fact that such malware can come with bonus trojans and keyloggers to get access to you backup accounts to get it all washed our. Great.

snippet.textDisplay: Bleh.. so you've sponsored to promote some antivirus/antimalware software with backup'n'recovery options. How does this compare to other antimalware software out there? F-Secure? Norton? Is it cheap? Is it more effective? What about the free ones out there? For me at least, there is absolutely nothing new or interesting in a antivirus software that detects and blocks vulnurability threats or a "have an backup!" -approach. So yeah, i think this video was with little interesting content and says nothing about if Acronis' product is even any good (compared to the others).
snippet.textOriginal: Bleh.. so you've sponsored to promote some antivirus/antimalware software with backup'n'recovery options. How does this compare to other antimalware software out there? F-Secure? Norton? Is it cheap? Is it more effective? What about the free ones out there? For me at least, there is absolutely nothing new or interesting in a antivirus software that detects and blocks vulnurability threats or a "have an backup!" -approach. snippet.textDisplay: Linus if you have the latest Microsoft Windows 10 updates plus the developers package you should be able to extract the encryption key that is listed by the Ransomware and then once you have that 4096 byte key from the start menu select Bash terminal ->Seahorse in seahorse paste in the encryption key and select retrieve the decryption key you might have to select sync before the wanted key appears then cut and paste the wanted 4096 byte key and  then paste it back to the ransomware key and hit enter and your files should come back that is the beauty of having the Seahorse RSA package and UBUNTU also installed inside Windows 10.
snippet.textOriginal: Linus if you have the latest Microsoft Windows 10 updates plus the developers package you should be able to extract the encryption key that is listed by the Ransomware and then once you have that 4096 byte key from the start menu select Bash terminal ->Seahorse in seahorse paste in the encryption key and select retrieve the decryption key you might have to select sync before the wanted key appears then cut and paste the wanted 4096 byte key and  then paste it back to the ransomware key and hit enter and your files should come back that is the beauty of having the Seahorse RSA package and UBUNTU also installed inside Windows 10.

snippet.textDisplay: A bit disappointed by this video, I thought acronis made a new feature doing a ransomware rollback but this is just making an image and restoring an old point in time. snippet.textDisplay: Anyone know if Acronis 2020 actually has the file/folders you exclude work to reduce the size of the incremental backups?  I have a lot of content change in folders that are excluded from system image backup and it still results in incremental backups that are nearly as big as the original “full disk image”. This means I am constantly having to upload huge incremental backups to the cloud when really only a small amount is changed.  So translation, does their dedupe incremental actually work?
snippet.textOriginal: Anyone know if Acronis 2020 actually has the file/folders you exclude work to reduce the size of the incremental backups?  I have a lot of content change in folders that are excluded from system image backup and it still results in incremental backups that are nearly as big as the original “full disk image”. This means I am constantly having to upload huge incremental backups to the cloud when really only a small amount is changed.  So translation, does their dedupe incremental actually work?

yeeah.. this dont defeat shit. if its a sleeper payload. it could have been on your system for months. then activated later. meaning your backups, even far back is also infected. then its GG.

snippet.textDisplay:
Used their 2018 version. Buggy, some features are half baked. Sync service was a complete joke. Their support from India tried its best, in the end, I correspondent with some kind of higher up and told him he makes @rap. Now I use Crashplan, they somehow solved their JAVA coding mess and work ok.

Acronic got some good features but they add too many half baked stuff. I mean its for backup so why you shove sync service that produces errors. Upload speed to EU Switzerland server was ok, I think 5Mbps. In conclusion, don't trust one vendor.
snippet.textOriginal:
Used their 2018 version. Buggy, some features are half baked. Sync service was a complete joke. Their support from India tried its best, in the end, I correspondent with some kind of higher up and told him he makes @rap. Now I use Crashplan, they somehow solved their JAVA coding mess and work ok. 

Acronic got some good features but they add too many half baked stuff. I mean its for backup so why you shove sync service that produces errors. Upload speed to EU Switzerland server was ok, I think 5Mbps. In conclusion, don't trust one vendor.
